Question: How do I ignore parentheses while using string tokenizer to read in fractions?: :public Fraction (String fractionString){  StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(fractionString, "/");  numerator = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());  denominator = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());}I have this so far.  How do I change this to ignore parentheses in a fraction?Example: (3/4) - how do I ignore these parentheses?Looking at this would I be able to simply do    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(fractionString, "/()"?
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.
Answer:
response:
Please answer my code questions using the given API following this format: <<<api>>>: $API
<<<code>>>: $CODE

Question: How do I ignore parentheses while using string tokenizer to read in fractions?: :public Fraction (String fractionString){  StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(fractionString, "/");  numerator = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());  denominator = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());}I have this so far.  How do I change this to ignore parentheses in a fraction?Example: (3/4) - how do I ignore these parentheses?Looking at this would I be able to simply do    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(fractionString, "/()"?
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.
Answer: You can use a regular expression to remove the parentheses from the string before tokenizing it. Here's how you can modify your code:

```java
import java.util.regex.*;

public Fraction (String fractionString){
    // Remove parentheses from the string
    fractionString = fractionString.replaceAll("\\(|\\)", "");

    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(fractionString, "/");
    numerator = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());
    denominator = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());
}
```

This code first removes all parentheses from the input string using the `replaceAll` method with a regular expression that matches either "(" or ")". Then it tokenizes the string as before.

Please note that this code assumes that the input string is always in the format "(numerator/denominator)". If the input string can have other formats, you may need to adjust the regular expression or the way you handle the string to correctly remove the parentheses.

Also, this code does not handle cases where the string does not contain exactly one "/" character or where the numerator or denominator cannot be parsed to an integer. You may want to add error checking code to handle these cases.
